metadata.title: Predictive Approximate Bayesian Computation via Saddle Points
metadata.author: Yingxiang Yang, Bo Dai, Negar Kiyavash, Niao He
metadata.journal: Conference on Neural Information Processing Systems
metadata.abstract: Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) is an important methodology for Bayesian inference when the likelihood function is intractable. Sampling-based ABC algorithms such as rejectionand K2-ABC are inefficient when the parameters have high dimensions, while the regression-based algorithms such as K-and DR-ABC are hard to scale. In this paper, we introduce an optimization-based ABC framework that addresses these deficiencies. Leveraging a generative model for posterior and joint distribution matching, we show that ABC can be framed as saddle point problems, whose objectives can be accessed directly with samples. We present the predictive ABC algorithm (P-ABC), and provide a probabilistically approximately correct (PAC) bound that guarantees its learning consistency. Numerical experiment shows that P-ABC outperforms both K2-and DR-ABC significantly.

highlights: Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) is an important methodology to perform Bayesian inference on complex models where likelihood functions are intractable

Our contributions are three-fold: First, we start with a generative model for posterior approximation and show that the Approximate Bayesian computation problem can be formulated as a saddle point optimization through both joint distribution matching and posterior matching
Predictive Approximate Bayesian computation (P-Approximate Bayesian computation), for solving the empirical counterpart of (4), in Algorithm 1

K2-and DR-Approximate Bayesian computation both need large number of samples drawn from the conditional distribution corresponding to the same parameter in order to compute the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) statistics accurately

We presented a unifying optimization framework for Approximate Bayesian computation, named Predictive-Approximate Bayesian computation, under which we showed that Approximate Bayesian computation can be formulated as a saddle point problem for different objective functions

We presented a high-probability error bound that decays at the speed of O(N −1/2 log N ) with N being the number of samples and we presented a stochastic-gradient-descent-based algorithm, P-Approximate Bayesian computation, to find the solution
key_statements: Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) is an important methodology to perform Bayesian inference on complex models where likelihood functions are intractable

Our contributions are three-fold: First, we start with a generative model for posterior approximation and show that the Approximate Bayesian computation problem can be formulated as a saddle point optimization through both joint distribution matching and posterior matching

We provide an efficient stochastic gradient descent-based algorithm for finding the saddle point, and provide a probabilistically approximately correct (PAC) bound guaranteeing the consistency of the solution to the problem

We introduce a new class of optimization objective that allows the learner to directly leverage the samples from the likelihood p(y|θ), which is available under the Approximate Bayesian computation setting, for estimating the posterior

We propose two models for approximate Bayesian computation, both of which can be reformulated as saddle point problems and can be solved by stochastic gradient algorithm.
2.1
Predictive Approximate Bayesian computation (P-Approximate Bayesian computation), for solving the empirical counterpart of (4), in Algorithm 1

K2-and DR-Approximate Bayesian computation both need large number of samples drawn from the conditional distribution corresponding to the same parameter in order to compute the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) statistics accurately
We examined the performance of P-Approximate Bayesian computation when the dimension of θ∗ was higher

We presented a unifying optimization framework for Approximate Bayesian computation, named Predictive-Approximate Bayesian computation, under which we showed that Approximate Bayesian computation can be formulated as a saddle point problem for different objective functions

We presented a high-probability error bound that decays at the speed of O(N −1/2 log N ) with N being the number of samples and we presented a stochastic-gradient-descent-based algorithm, P-Approximate Bayesian computation, to find the solution
summary: Approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) is an important methodology to perform Bayesian inference on complex models where likelihood functions are intractable.
In DR-ABC, the posterior is obtained by performing a distribution regression using the given samples.

Our contributions are three-fold: First, we start with a generative model for posterior approximation and show that the ABC problem can be formulated as a saddle point optimization through both joint distribution matching and posterior matching.

We introduce a new class of optimization objective that allows the learner to directly leverage the samples from the likelihood p(y|θ), which is available under the ABC setting, for estimating the posterior.
We propose two models for approximate Bayesian computation, both of which can be reformulated as saddle point problems and can be solved by stochastic gradient algorithm.

The proposed optimization framework for posterior matching does not restrict the testing function to an RKHS, and the saddle point objective (6) is an exact reformulation of (5), rather than an upper bound.

K2-and DR-ABC both need large number of samples drawn from the conditional distribution corresponding to the same parameter in order to compute the maximum mean discrepancy (MMD) statistics accurately.

Consider a toy example where we observe a set of samples Y ∗ := {yi∗}ni=1 where all yi∗’s correspond to the same underlying parameter θ∗ ∈ Rp. We assume the generating model is yi∗ = θ∗ + ui with {ui}ni=1 being i.i.d. random vectors and each dimension of ui as well as each dimension of θ∗ is uniformly distributed on [−0.5, 0.5].
We tested the performance of P-ABC, when the neural networks representing f and u in (4) were trained on 1000 samples.
We used neural networks to represent f and u in P-ABC, for which we trained with 1000 sets of samples.
For P-ABC, we adopted the same network structures for the neural networks representing f and g as in the previous example, and trained them with 4000 sets of samples.
We presented a unifying optimization framework for ABC, named Predictive-ABC, under which we showed that ABC can be formulated as a saddle point problem for different objective functions.

We presented a high-probability error bound that decays at the speed of O(N −1/2 log N ) with N being the number of samples and we presented a stochastic-gradient-descent-based algorithm, P-ABC, to find the solution.
P-ABC significantly outperforms K2-and DR-ABC, representatives for the state-of-the-art samplingand regression-based algorithms, respectively
headline: We introduce an optimization-based Approximate Bayesian computation framework that addresses these deficiencies
